The spell has no effect, other than to be stored in the device. If the device can't hold the spell, the spell is expended without effect. The device regains 1 charge for each level of spell slot used.
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

Orville examined the strange device that he had just unearthed. It gleamed and glinted in the torchlight, despite its apparent age, and the craftsmanship was like nothing he had ever seen. He traced his finger along the intricate grooves and amber-like appendages, daydreaming about the people who could have crafted such a curious contraption.

item.name: Lucky Material Pouch
entries: A small magical bag that always seems to have the material you need at the bottom of it. As an action, you can reach out and draw out any crafting material worth 1 gp or less. After each time you do so, roll a {@dice d4}. On a 1, the bag is empty and no more materials can be retrieved until the next dawn.

item.name: Magic Diamond
entries: This diamond gives off 5 feet of bright light and 5 feet of dim light when not socketed. When socketed into a weapon, the weapon becomes magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance. When socketed into a ring or necklace, a creature wearing that piece of jewelry can use their action to cast the {@spell Force Bolt|KibblesTasty:cc} {@sup K} cantrip.

item.name: Magician's Wand
entries: This wand has has 6 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 of its charges to cast {@spell minor illusion}. When you cast {@spell minor illusion} using this wand, you have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks involving tricks or illusions until the end of your turn.
The wand regains {@dice 1d4 + 2} expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the wand breaks.

item.name: Mechanical Arm
entries: A functional mechanical arm that can replace a missing one. This works for either a biological creature or a construct. This item follows the rules for attunement, but doesn't require an attunement slot once attuned. While attuned in this way, it functions the same as the limb it replaces.

item.name: Mechanical Leg
entries: A functional mechanical leg that can replace a missing one. This works for either a biological creature or a construct. This item follows the rules for attunement, but doesn't require an attunement slot once attuned. While attuned in this way, it functions the same as the limb it replaces.

item.name: Mimic Heart
entries: This strange ever shifting fleshy organ has potent shifting properties that can make the following Exotic Potions.
When added to a {@item Potion of Climbing}, it turns it into a Potion of Alter Self, granting the effect of the spell {@spell alter self} for 1 hour (no {@condition concentration} required).

When added to a {@item Potion of Growth} along with at least one other {@item rare reactive reagent|KTKCG} ingredient, it becomes a Potion of Polymorph granting the effect of the {@spell polymorph} spell for 10 minutes (no {@condition concentration} required).

item.name: Mind Shard
entries: A crystalized beacon of pure telepathic power. A holder of this stone can cast {@spell command} and {@spell charm person} at will. The stone has 8 charges, regaining {@dice 1d6 + 2} at dawn. You can expend 2 charges to cast {@spell suggestion}, 5 charges to cast {@spell dominate person}, or 8 charges to cast {@spell dominate monster}.

item.name: Mint Chew
entries: A chewy minty candy. You can pop one into your mouth as a bonus action. While being chewed (for up to 10 minutes), you are energized and can ignore the effects of up to 3 levels of {@condition exhaustion} for the duration, and can't be put to sleep by magical means.
You can only gain this benefit once per day, after which consuming additional pieces of the candy has no effect until you finish a long rest.

item.name: Morph Cookies
entries: Consuming one of these has the effects of casting {@spell alter self}, however you can't change the adaptation unless you consume another cookie. This effect doesn't require {@condition concentration} to maintain, and can be extended by consuming an additional morph cookie.
If the ingredient came from a {@creature mimic|MM}, you can additionally transform your appearance to creatures with a different basic shape than you, though you remain the same size.

item.name: Nail Bomb
entries: A brutal instrument, this mixes explosive powder and nails to create a devastating fragmentation device. An exceedingly dangerous device. Heavier and more deadly than other explosives, the primary damage comes from the metal shrapnel (nails) flung in all directions. It can be detonated by dealing 1 fire or lightning damage to it. As an action, a packet of this explosive can be accurately thrown 20 feet, but will not detonate on impact (usually). When it detonates, all creatures within 20 feet of the target point must make a Dexterity saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Alchemy DC. On failure, they take {@damage 8d4} piercing damage, or half as much on a success.

You can fuse your explosives. When fused, intentionally dealing fire damage to the explosives (or otherwise lighting the fuse) causes it to detonate on a delay, selected from: short (the end of your turn), medium (the start of your next turn), and long (2 rounds, at the start of your turn).

item.name: Old Reliable
entries: Applied to a melee weapon or up to 5 pieces of ammunition. This poison is exceptionally durable, lasting on a weapon for 1 hour and an unlimited number of hits during that time. On hit, weapons with this poison applied deal {@damage 1d4} additional poison damage.

item.name: Ordinary Walking Stick
entries: You can use a bonus action to twist the shaft of this {@item quarterstaff|PHB} and deploy or retract the limbs of a {@item light crossbow|PHB} built into its head. It is indistinguishable from a walking stick while the limbs are retracted. It functions as a {@item quarterstaff|PHB} in either mode, however it only functions as a crossbow when the limbs are deployed. This crossbow lacks the {@itemProperty LD||loading} property and is fitted with an internal magazine that can hold up to six crossbow bolts. It automatically reloads after firing until the magazine runs out of ammunition. Reloading the magazine takes an action. You are proficient with this magical weapon if you are proficient in either light crossbows or quarterstaffs.
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

item.name: Panacea
entries: When you drink this potion, you regain all lost hit points, all status effects are removed, all reductions to ability scores are removed, any missing limbs are restored, all diseases are cured, all curses are removed, and all levels of {@condition exhaustion} are removed, and you cease to age for 1 year. This potion can remove effects that can otherwise only be removed by wish.
If you ever drink a second panacea potion, make a {@dc 30} Constitution saving throw. On failure, you gain no benefits from it and die.

item.name: Paralyzing Poison
entries: Applied to a melee weapon or up to 5 pieces of ammunition. A creature subjected to this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC.

On failure, the target becomes {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. A creature is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} this way. At the end of each of the creature's turns, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on success.
Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying, and wears off of a weapon after that weapon has delivered the effect 5 times.

item.name: Payload Shot
entries: This shot can be fired at half the normal range of the weapon firing it. You can deliever any object less than 2 inches in any dimension weighing less than 2 pounds to a target creature or point within that range. When you recover this arrow, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 1, it is broken.

item.name: Perfect Infusion
entries: A gem infused so perfectly that it readily accepts power. You can activate this gem as a reaction when you take acid, cold, fire, lightning or thunder damage. The gem grants you resistance to the triggering damage type until the start of your next turn. After triggering it, the first time you hit with a melee attack on your next turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} elemental damage of the triggering type. Once activated, it can't be activated again until you finish a long rest.

item.name: Potent Alchemical Acid
entries: A small flask of burbling acid, a strange hissing green viscous liquid. It deals {@damage 6d4} acid damage when poured on an object. Can be used as a simple ranged weapon with the thrown (20/60) property, dealing {@damage 6d4} acid damage on hit. You do not add your modifier to the damage roll.

item.name: Potent Alchemical Fire
entries: A small flask of volatile orange liquid. It deals {@damage 3d10} fire damage when poured on an object. Can be used as a simple ranged weapon with the thrown (20/60) property, dealing {@damage 3d10} fire damage on hit. You do not add your modifier to the damage roll.

item.name: Potent Contact Poison
entries: Applied to an object. The first creature that touches that object after it is applied must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC.

On failure, they take {@damage 4d4} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. At the end of a {@condition poisoned} creature's turn, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the condition on success.

item.name: Potent Explosive
entries: A bundled explosive alchemical preparation. It can be detonated by dealing 1 fire or lightning damage to it. As an action, a packet of this explosive can be accurately thrown 20 feet, but will not detonate on impact (usually). When it detonates, all creatures within 15 feet (for uncommon) of the target point must make a Dexterity saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Alchemy DC. On failure, they take {@damage 2d8} fire + {@damage 2d8} thunder damage, or half as much on a success. Creatures in range of more than one explosive take damage only from the highest damage effect.

item.name: Potent Ingested Poison
entries: A creature subjected to this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC. On failure, they take {@damage 3d6} poison damage and suffer the {@condition poisoned} condition for 1 hour.

item.name: Potent Inhaled Poison
entries: When released, this poison fills a 10-foot radius around the source. You can accurately throw a vial of it (shattering on impact) at a point up to 30 feet away, or release it by other means. A creature subjected to this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC.

On failure, they take {@damage 2d4} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. At the end of a {@condition poisoned} creature's turn, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the condition on success.

This effect lingers in the area it was released for {@dice 1d4} rounds. A strong wind will clear away and disperse the poison. A creature that enters the area for the first time must save against the poison.

item.name: Potent Injury Poison
entries: Applied to a melee weapon or up to 5 pieces of ammunition. A creature subjected to this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC.

On failure, they take {@damage 2d6} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. At the end of a {@condition poisoned} creature's turn, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the condition on success.
Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying, and wears off of a weapon after that weapon has delivered the effect 5 times.

item.name: Potion Fridgebox
entries: This resembles a small wooden box that can fit a container carrying up to a gallon of liquid in it. You can place unfinished potions, brews, or similar items in it, pausing the crafting time on it, allowing you to resume crafting it the item at a later time.
You can also store perishable liquids in this fridge, and they will not spoil.

item.name: Power
entries: A vibrant rune with intricate line work that shines a bright cyan.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When wearing armor or an item marked with this rune, once per turn when the wearer rolls for damage with a spell, they can maximize one die of the damage roll. When wielding a weapon marked with this rune, the damage of that weapon is considered magical, and once per turn, when the wielder rolls damage for an attack with that weapon, they can maximize one damage die.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, when you cast a spell, you can use this rune to empower it, casting it as if it was one level higher. Once activated, it can't be activated again until the next dawn.

item.name: Powerful Alchemical Acid
entries: A small flask of burbling acid, a strange hissing green viscous liquid. It deals {@damage 8d4} acid damage when poured on an object. Can be used as a simple ranged weapon with the thrown (20/60) property, dealing {@damage 8d4} acid damage on hit. You do not add your modifier to the damage roll.

item.name: Powerful Alchemical Fire
entries: A small flask of volatile orange liquid. It deals {@damage 4d10} fire damage when poured on an object. Can be used as a simple ranged weapon with the thrown (20/60) property, dealing {@damage 4d10} fire damage on hit. You do not add your modifier to the damage roll.

item.name: Powerful Explosive
entries: A bundled explosive alchemical preparation. It can be detonated by dealing 1 fire or lightning damage to it. As an action, a packet of this explosive can be accurately thrown 20 feet, but will not detonate on impact (usually). When it detonates, all creatures within 20 feet (for rare) of the target point must make a Dexterity saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Alchemy DC. On failure, they take {@damage 4d8} fire + {@damage 4d8} thunder damage, or half as much on a success. Creatures in range of more than one explosive take damage only from the highest damage effect.

item.name: Protection
entries: A complicated rune with twisting multilayered geometric markings that glimmers a dull grey.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on armor or an item, any time an attuned wearer takes damage, that damage is reduced by 1.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can use that item to cast {@spell shield} without expending a spell slot. Once a rune's power is used, the rune's active can't be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Purity of Mind
item.reqAttune: by a psionic character with one or more psi points
entries: A blindfold made of heavy silken cloth, it is emblazoned with strange patterns. When worn, you are lose any normal vision that relies on your eyes and are {@condition blinded} but gain several benefits as your mind is cleared of visual distractions.

items: You gain a {@sense mindsight|KTKCG} of 60 feet, allowing you to see creatures with an intelligence of 6 or higher within range as if by {@sense blindsight}. A creature you are unaware of can still be hidden from you.
You gain a {@sense blindsight} of 10 feet. If you already have a {@sense blindsight}, its range is increased by 10 feet.
You are immune to effects that require you to see the target or effect, even if they are within your {@sense mindsight|KTKCG} or {@sense blindsight}.

item.name: Quantum Chaos Box
entries: This is a mysterious box that harnesses primordial chaos to manipulate aspects of reality within it, creating random chaotic things. When opening this box, roll a {@dice 1d12} to determine the results. If opened again, the box is empty until the next dawn.

entries.name: Additional Effects
entries: An ambitious GM can replace any effect rolled with a new effect (either positive or negative) to keep the box indefinitely chaotic. Ideas that might lead to further adventures can even be included. Imagine the ramifications of opening the box and finding a {@creature lich|MM|lich's} phylactery.

item.name: Quickening Candies
entries: A small hard candy ball, with extreme caffineated properties. When you pop one of these into your mouth as a bonus action, you are under the effect of {@spell haste} for {@dice 1d4} rounds. You still suffer the normal effect of {@spell haste} ending when the effect ends.

item.name: Raiment of the Raccoon
entries: You have a +1 bonus to AC while wearing this armor. While wearing it, you are imbued with the hardiness of a raccoon. Your rogue feature {@classFeature Evasion|Rogue||7} now applies to Constitution saving throws as well.

entries.name: Keen Sense of Touch
entries: While wearing this armor you develop a hypersensitive tactile awareness. You can add your Wisdom modifier to Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks, {@item thieves' tools|PHB} checks and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks that use your sense of touch. You can reliably detect the surface details, such as engraved writing or material properties, of an object by touching it.

entries.name: Curse
entries: While attuned to this armor you become obsessively hygienic. You must spend at least 10 minutes washing your hands to benefit from a short or long rest and you prefer to dunk your food into water before eating it.
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

item.name: Rapidfire Heavy Crossbow
entries: This lever-action heavy crossbow is auto-drawing and magazine-fed. A revolving cylinder ringed with magnetic chambers grabs and nocks bolts from the magazine to be fired in rapid succession.

This crossbow lacks the {@itemProperty LD||loading} property and is fitted with a cartridge that can hold up to twenty crossbow bolts. It automatically reloads after firing until the cartridge runs out of ammunition. Reloading the cartridge takes 1 minute.
You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you use the {@action Attack} action with this crossbow, you can use a bonus action to attack again with it.
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

item.name: Reality
entries: A fanciful twisting rune that confuses the eye with ever shifting patterns of colors.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on an item, an attuned wearer can cast ever more convincing illusions. Creatures have disadvantage on their first Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to determine if a spell you cast is an illusion (the first check it makes against that spell).

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: You can cause one illusion you've made to become real. This effects a 10 foot by 10 foot cube of the illusion if it is larger than that. This can't create an object worth more than 100 gp, lasts 1 hour, and can't create a creature of a CR greater than 5 (when attempting to, it may create a weakened version of that creature, or simply fail). If the illusion directly causes damage (from falling on a creature, or otherwise being harmful) it can deal a maximum of {@damage 8d8} damage (potentially split across multiple creatures). This limit doesn't apply to creatures created through it. Once activated, it can't be activated again until the next dawn.

item.name: Resonating Crystal
item.reqAttune: by a psionic character with one or more psi points
entries: This is a crystal that has been fundamentally warped by exposure to psionic powers. It now holds the perfect resonance to trap and hold psionic energy, though it doesn't naturally generate it.

While holding this crystal, as an action you can imbue up to 4 psi points into it. While it is imbued it gives off 10 feet of bright light and 10 feet of dim light with a eerie purple hue. If it has one or more points imbued in it, as an action you can reclaim the psi points stored in it, regaining expended psi points from it up to your maximum psi points.

item.name: Ricochet Shot
entries: If you hit an attack roll with it, you can make another attack roll against another target within 10 feet of the first as part of the same attack when firing this shot. When you recover this arrow, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 1, it is broken.

item.name: Ring of Labor
entries: A simple copper band. You can use this ring to cast {@spell unseen crafter|KTKCG}. Once used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Savage Talisman
entries: While wearing the talisman, you gain a +1 bonus to the attack rolls and the damage rolls you make with unarmed strikes and natural weapons. Such attacks are considered to be magical.

item.name: Scale Mail of the Pangolin
entries: While wearing this armor you gain a burrowing speed of 10 feet. You can use your burrowing speed to move through sand, loose earth, mud, or ice, not solid rock.

This armor can adjust itself to provide superior protection, allowing you to curl up into a ball as an action. Until you emerge (on your turn, no action required), you gain a +5 bonus to AC, and you have advantage on Strength and Constitution saving throws. While curled up, you are {@condition prone}, your speed is 0 and can't increase, you have disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws, and you are {@condition incapacitated}. {@action Attack} rolls made against you do not have advantage normally granted by the {@condition prone} condition. Additionally, a creature can roll you along the ground in front of itself if it succeeds on a {@dc 10} Strength check (no action required).
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

item.name: Seaworthy Bouillabaisse
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this hearty meal, you become satiated for the next 24 hours. The magical properties of the meal grant you immunity to sea sickness as well as advantage on Dexterity or Constitution saving throws involving the motion of sea vessels.
Additionally, if you do not have proficiency in Water Vehicles, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded down) to any check involving them for the duration.

item.name: Seeing Sticks
entries: A stick of hard tacky substance. You can pop one into your mouth as a bonus action. While being sucked (for up to 10 minutes), you gain expanded senses and have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks, saving throws against Illusion spells, and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks to see through illusions, though because of the bad taste inherent to the formulation, continuing to suck on the seeing stick requires {@condition concentration}, as if concentrating on a spell.

By adding the optional {@item common supplies|KTKCG} ingredient, they can be sweetened, granting you advantage on Constitution saving throws made to maintain your {@condition concentration} against spitting them out; this increases the DC of the recipe by 1.

item.name: Shawm of Sundering
entries: When a creature adds one of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard||1} dice to an attack or damage roll, and they hit a target within 60 feet of you, you can play the {@item shawm|PHB} as a reaction to deal thunder damage equal to one roll of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard||1} die to the target.

Additionally, you can play the {@item shawm|PHB} as an action to cast {@spell thunderwave}, {@spell shatter}, or {@spell lightning bolt}, and that spell can't be cast from it again until the next dawn.
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

item.name: Silver Oil
entries: A sparkling chromatic oil. The oil can coat one slashing or piercing weapon or up to 5 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition. Applying the oil takes 1 minute. For 1 hour, the coated item is considered silvered.

item.name: Simple Contact Poison
entries: Applied to an object. The first creature that touches must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC or take {@damage 2d4} poison damage, after which the poison is rubbed off.

item.name: Simple Ingested Poison
entries: Applied to food or beverage. A creature that consumes this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC. On failure, they take {@damage 2d6} poison damage and suffer the {@condition poisoned} condition for 1 hour.

item.name: Simple Inhaled Poison
entries: When released, this poison fills a 10-foot radius around the source. You can accurately throw a vial of it (shattering on impact) at a point up to 30 feet away, or release it by other means. A creature subjected to this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC. On failure, they take {@damage 2d4} poison damage.

item.name: Simple Injury Poison
entries: Applied to a melee weapon or up to 5 pieces of ammunition. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC or take {@damage 2d4} poison damage.
Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying, and wears off of a weapon after that weapon has delivered the effect 5 times.

item.name: Size
entries: A rune of layered circles with a pale green light flowing through them.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on armor or an item, an attuned wearer grows 1 foot, counts as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift. When marked on a weapon, the weapon grows larger when wielded by an attuned wielder and gains the {@itemProperty H||heavy} property if it doesn't already have it (losing the {@itemProperty L||light} property if it has the {@itemProperty L||light} property).

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can use that item to cast {@spell enlarge/reduce} as a bonus action without expending a spell slot. Once a rune's power is used, the rune's active can't be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Skill
entries: An intricate rune that pulses with swirling lights, varying in design to incorporate a mark of the skill granted.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on an item, an attuned wearer gains proficiency in one skill, selected when the rune is marked by the creator of the rune.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can activate this rune gain advantage on an ability check for the skill granted by this rune. Once activated, it can't be activated again until the next dawn.

item.name: Slow Death
entries: Applied to food or beverage. A creature that consumes this poison begins to slowly die if they aren't immune to poison. Each time that creature finishes a long rest, its hit point maximum is reduced by 1. If the creature's hit point maximum hit is reduced to 0 by this effect, it dies. While its hit points are less than half of its original maximum, it is {@condition poisoned}. This effect can be removed by effects that remove the {@condition poisoned} condition, and can be only be identified by magic or a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check.
If a creature is cured, it regains its lost hit points after it finishes a long rest.

item.name: Smoke Powder
entries: A fine grey powder with large grains and the faint smell of sulfur and charcoal that comes in small packets weighing 1/2 pound.

When ignited by 1 or more fire or lightning damage, it releases a blast of thick black smoke that fills a 20-foot radius. Everything in this smoke is {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2||heavily obscured} for {@dice 2d4} rounds. At the start of your next turn after the number of rounds rolled, the smoke begins to fade leaving everything within the radius {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2||lightly obscured}, and it clears completely at the start of your next turn after that.
Additional uses of the smoke powder extend the duration of {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2||heavy obscurement} for an extra {@dice 1d4} rounds.

item.name: Soul Shard
item.reqAttune: by a psionic character with one or more psi points
entries: A crystalized fragment of a dead psionic creature. How these form, few know. Many suspect dark secrets at their origin. These shards can be driven into the flesh of another psionic creature, dealing {@damage 1d4} piercing damage and {@damage 4d12} psychic damage and causing them to instantly become attuned to it. When you do so, you gain access to a Psionic Discipline that the creature it was formed from presumably had, along with one flaw formed from the fragment of their soul within the shard.

When you find a soul shard, the GM can determine the Discipline it contains and the flaw it confers while attuned, you can roll on the following table to determine them. To unattune to it, must spend an action to try to rip it free. You must succeed a {@dc 15} Charsma saving throw. Each time you fail this this save, you take {@damage 4d12} psychic damage.

item.name: Space
entries: A deceptively simply rune made of up lines of varying lengths in an odd arrangement that glows a steady dim grey light.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: On your turn, you can replace your movement by teleporting 10 feet in any direction to an empty space you can see.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: You can cast {@spell dimension door} without expending a spell slot. Once activated, it can't be activated again until the next dawn.

item.name: Sparkling Sapphire
entries: This sapphire sparkles dimly with an internal light. A creature can infuse a 1st-level spell or cantrip into this gem, causing it to sparkle more brilliant. Subsequently, a creature hold the gem, a weapon the gem is socketed into, or a piece of jewelry the gem is socketed into, can cast the spell as if they are casting the spell. If the creature has a spellcasting feature, they can use it to cast the spell without expending a spell slot, discharging the power in the gem. If a creature doesn't have the spellcasting feature, their spell attack modifier is +3 and their spell save DC is 11 for any spell cast. The effects of a spell cast using this sapphire can't persist for more than 10 minute (for example, a {@spell find familiar|PHB|familiar} summoned with it would last 10 minutes rather than indefinitely).

item.name: Specialized Mechanical Arm
entries: A functional mechanical arm that can replace a missing one. This works for either a biological creature or a construct. This item follows the rules for attunement, but doesn't require an attunement slot once attuned. While attuned in this way, it functions the same as the limb it replaces. Additionally, this arm can house a tool of your choice.

item.name: Speed
entries: A flickering white rune with jagged lines.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on armor or an item, an attuned wearer can take the {@action dash} action as a bonus action on their turn. When marked on a weapon with {@itemProperty L||light} property, an attuned wearer can make a single weapon {@action attack} with the bonus action on their turn.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can use that item to cast {@spell haste} without expending a spell slot. Once activated, it can't be activated again until the next dawn.

item.name: Spell Shot
entries: A magically infused arrow. It comes in three different types, based on what kind of magic is infused in it.

items: Fog Cloud. You can target a creature or a point within the normal range of your weapon with this arrow. This functions as a normal piece of ammunition, but casts {@spell fog cloud} at the point of impact. The spell lasts {@dice 1d4} rounds and doesn't require {@condition concentration}.

Entangle. You can target a creature or a point within the normal range of your weapon with this arrow. This functions as a normal piece of ammunition, but casts {@spell entangle} at the point of impact. The spell lasts {@dice 1d4} rounds and doesn't require {@condition concentration}.
Multishot. When you fire this arrow, you cast {@spell multishot|KibblesTasty:CC}.

entries: Once the magic effect is discharged by firing it, the magic of the arrow is expended, and it becomes a mundane arrow.

item.name: Spiked Shield
entries: Your shield is considered a martial melee weapon, dealing {@damage 1d4} damage on hit.

item.name: Spring Loaded Leg
entries: A functional mechanical leg that can replace a missing one. While attuned in this way, it functions the same as the limb it replaces. Additionally, it can absorb a great deal of impact when falling and spring to new heights. You can reduce all falling damage by 20 feet, and your jumping distance is doubled. After falling, your jumping distance is further increased by a quarter of the distance fallen.

item.name: Squall Caller
entries: This battleaxe has the thrown property with a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet. It has 3 charges. While holding the battleaxe, you can use an action and expend 1 charge to cast {@spell gust of wind} (save {@dc 13}) from it. The Squall Caller regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

entries.name: Amplified
entries: If the {@item Squall Collar|KTKCG} is within 60 feet of this battleaxe, it gains the following properties:

items: You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
Immediately after being thrown, the battleaxe flies back to your hand.
The saving throw DC for spells cast from the battleaxe increases to 15.

When you cast {@spell gust of wind} from the battleaxe, the distance pushed increases by 5 feet and you can choose any number of creatures within the area of effect to automatically succeed on their saving throw. Additionally, you can choose to cast {@spell gust of wind} without requiring {@condition concentration}, but the spell ends at the start of your next turn.

entries: {@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

item.name: Squall Collar
entries: This cold steel choker is forged into the shape of a roiling storm. It gives you a static shock when touched. It has 3 charges. While wearing the collar, you can use an action and expend 1 charge to cast {@spell sleet storm} (save {@dc 15}) from it. The Squall Collar regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

entries.name: Amplified
entries: If the {@item Squall Caller|KTKCG} is within 60 feet of this collar, it gains the following properties:

items: Wearing the collar allows you to see normally through heavily obscured areas caused by weather or spells such as {@spell sleet storm} or {@spell fog cloud}.
The saving throw DC for spells cast from the collar increases to 16.
When you are targeted with an attack that deals thunder or lightning damage, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to the triggering damage type until the start of your next turn.
Additionally, the Squall Caller deals an extra {@damage 1d8} of the triggering damage type for 1 minute.

entries: Once the collar is used in this way, the ability cannot be used again until the next dawn.
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

item.name: Sticky Goo
entries: When broken and exposed to air, it creates a very sticky rapidly expanding web like foam, with the effect of the spell {@spell web} centered on where the flask breaks. You can reliably throw the flask to a target point within 30 feet, shattering it on impact.

item.name: Superb Feast
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this hearty meal, you become satiated for the next 24 hours. You gain the benefits for a {@item common feast|KTKCG}, but can gain additional benefits by trading in Hit Dice that would be gained as part of your next long rest after consuming this meal. These Hit Dice are consumed after calculating how many you would have after the rest (including the benefits of the feast), but you can trade Hit Dice in this way you would normally lose if you have more than your maximum Hit Dice.
You can trade Hit Dice in this way up to a number equal to your proficiency bonus. The benefits scale based on the rarity on the feast.

entries.name: Very Rare Benefits
items: Roll a {@dice d8} per Hit Die traded and gain temporary hit points equal to the value rolled.
Trade three Hit Dice for an additional spell slot of 3rd level.
Gain a point that can be expended like Inspiration by trading 3 Hit Dice per point.

entries: Any benefit from a feast fades after 24 hours.

item.name: Superb Meat Feast
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this hearty meal, you become satiated for the next 24 hours. Consuming the essence of a properly prepared creature of great power confers some of its power to you while satiated by the feast.

You can add +3 to ability checks and saving throws of the prepared creatures highest stat (if multiple stats are tied, the cook chooses which when preparing the meal). Alternatively, the cook can bring forth exotic properties of the creature, conferring one trait of the cooked animal to those that consume it as per the following table (this replaces the benefit to ability checks and saves):

entries.caption: Meat Feast Boons
rows: Hold Breath, Keen Senses, Pounce, Stone Camouflage

entries: The details from the creature boon can be found on the creature stat block. The cook must be aware of the creature's property to make the meal imbue that property, and the GM may adjust the property in cases where it would not work for players or be too powerful as written. At the GM's discretion, any ability can be added to this list.

item.name: Tanning Bag
entries: A magical satchel. If you put an unprocessed {@item hide|KTKCG} into this bag, and speak one of three magic words. Depending on the word, the hide will be processed into {@item rawhide leather|KTKCG}, {@item boiled leather|KTKCG}, or {@item tanned leather|KTKCG}. This process takes 4 hours, and you can process one piece of hide at a time.

item.name: Theurge's Librum
entries: This hefty ornate {@item spellbook|PHB} remains pristine in all conditions, its cover depicting detailed sacred inscriptions. After studying the contents of this book for 8 hours, the user can comprehend a unifying theory of divine and arcane power, though such a comprehension mystically fades from the mind if they ever lose possession or unattune from the librum, until they are once more in possession and attuned to the librum.

When found, the librum contains the following spells: {@spell cure wounds}, {@spell bless}, {@spell lesser restoration}, {@spell gentle repose}, {@spell revivify}, {@spell spirit guardians}, {@spell commune}, {@spell guardian of faith}, {@spell dawn|XGE}, and {@spell mass cure wounds}. The spells contained within can be prepared as Wizard spells for the attuned user, but can't be copied out of the spell book. Casting these divine spells exerts a special strain on a wizard, however, and they can only cast a total number of spell slots of spells that do not appear on the Wizard list from this book equal to their Wizard level, after which they must finish a long rest, refreshing the number of spells they can cast.

In addition, it contains 10 empty pages, each of which can contain one additional spell from the cleric list. If you come across a cleric spell in written form (such as a {@item scroll|KTKCG}) the spell can be permenantly copied into the librum, expending one of the empty pages. The process of copying the spell into your ritual book takes 2 hours per level of the spell, and costs 50 gp per level. The cost represents the material components you expend as you experiment with the spell to master it, as well as the fine inks you need to record it.

item.name: Thunder Cannon
entries: The principle weapon of a Thundersmith.

item.name: Time
entries: A complicated geometric rune that slowly pulses with pale grey light.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on armor or an item, your speed increases by 20 feet, you gain a +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws, and you can take two reactions per round, though you can't take multiple reactions on the same turn. You age twice as fast while attuned to this rune.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can use that item to cast {@spell time stop} without expending a spell slot. Alternatively, you can use this rune as a reaction failing a Dexterity saving throw or being hit by an attack to automatically pass a Dexterity saving throw, or cause an attack to miss. You can use this ability after the roll to change its outcome. Once activated, it can't be activated again until the next dawn.

item.name: Tower Shield
entries: This is a massive unwieldy {@item shield|PHB}. While carrying it, your speed is reduced by 10 feet. At the end of each of your turns, pick a direction. You have {@quickref cover|PHB|3|0|half cover} from attacks in a cone that direction. Alternatively, you can pick a single target, tracking the movement. You have {@quickref cover|PHB|3|0|half cover} against attacks from that target (and only that target).

item.name: Uncommon Meat Feast
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this hearty meal, you become satiated for the next 24 hours. Consuming the essence of a properly prepared creature of great power confers some of its power to you while satiated by the feast.

You can add +1 to ability checks and saving throws of the prepared creatures highest stat (if multiple stats are tied, the cook chooses which when preparing the meal). Alternatively, the cook can bring forth exotic properties of the creature, conferring one trait of the cooked animal to those that consume it as per the following table (this replaces the benefit to ability checks and saves):

entries.caption: Meat Feast Boons
rows: Hold Breath, Keen Senses, Pounce, Stone Camouflage

entries: The details from the creature boon can be found on the creature stat block. The cook must be aware of the creature's property to make the meal imbue that property, and the GM may adjust the property in cases where it would not work for players or be too powerful as written. At the GM's discretion, any ability can be added to this list.

item.name: Underwater Breathing Apparatus
entries: The wearer can breath underwater for up to 1 hour. You can't (intelligibly) speak or perform verbal spell components while wearing this device.

item.name: Veins of Tar
entries: Applied to food or beverage. A creature that consumes this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC. On failure, they are under the effect of the {@spell slow} spell for 8 hours. This effect can be removed by effects that remove poison.

item.name: Vigor
entries: A bold rune with intertwined lines that hums slightly, beating with a faint red light.

entries.name: Passive Effects
entries: When marked on armor or an item, an attuned wearer can spend a Hit Die as a bonus action, rolling it and regaining hit points as normal. When marked on a weapon, an attuned wielder gains temporary hit points equal to the Constitution modifier when dealing damage to a living target.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can use that item to cast {@spell cure wounds} (2nd level) as a bonus action without expending a spell slot. Once a rune's power is used, the rune's active can't be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Vision
entries: An eye shaped rune the dimly pulses a faint purple light.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on armor or an item, an attuned wearer grains {@sense darkvision} with a range of 30 feet. If the the attuned wearer already has {@sense darkvision}, the range of the {@sense darkvision} increases by 30 feet.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can grant yourself 60 feet of {@sense blindsight} as a bonus action. This lasts until the start of your next turn. Once a rune's power is used, the rune's active can't be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Vision Stone
entries: A creature holding this crystal can view or record a single scene within in, viewed as if by the recording creatures eyes. This memory can be up to 1 minute long, and includes sights, sounds, and faint emotions. A memory can be faked, but doing so requires exceptional deception to make it seem accurate. When storing a fake memory make an Intelligence ({@skill Deception}) check. A viewer can detect a fake memory with a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check equal to or higher than to the {@skill deception} check minus 5.

item.name: Wand of Chores
entries: This wand has 6 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 of its charges to cast {@spell prestidigitation}.

The wand regains {@dice 1d4 + 2} expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the wand breaks, dumping the last 10 instances of filth it has cleaned up.

item.name: Watch
entries: A small time piece that accurately tracks time. Must be wound up every day or it will cease to track time.

item.name: Weaponized Arm
entries: A functional mechanical arm that can replace a missing one. This works for either a biological creature or a construct. This item follows the rules for attunement, but doesn't require an attunement slot once attuned. While attuned in this way, it functions the same as the limb it replaces. Additionally, this arm can house a one-handed melee weapon of your choice. This weapon can be swapped out as part of a short or long rest.

item.name: What Doesn't Kill You... Feast
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this dubious meal, you gain resistance to poison damage, and gain advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned} for 24 hours.

If the source of a poison saving throw is the same as the source of the {@item meat|KTKCG} or {@item poisonous reagent|KTKCG} used to make the feast, the advantage against being poisoned by that creature or effect lasts one week.

item.name: Whispers of Madness
entries: Applied to an object. The first creature that touches must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC. On failure, the character becomes {@condition poisoned} for 10 minutes, and rolls on the {@table Short-Term Madness|DMG|short term madness table}. They are under the effect of the rolled madness while {@condition poisoned}.

item.name: Whisperstick
entries: This wand has 6 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 of its charges to cast {@spell message}. You need to point the wand at the target to cast it in this way.
The wand regains {@dice 1d4 + 2} expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the wand breaks, making a loud bang audible up to 100 feet.

item.name: Whistling Shot
entries: When fired, this shot emits a shrill whistle that can be heard from up to 500 feet from where it is fired and its target point.

item.name: Windup Timer
entries: A small timer that can be set to accurately count down time, up to 4 hours, making a clanging noise at the end of the time.

entries.name: Advanced Timers
entries: If players wish to make a timer that does something other than make a noise at the completion, they likely can, but the GM can determine if additional challenge is involved (such as a timer that lights a fuse upon completion).

item.name: Withering Soul
entries: Applied to a melee weapon or up to 5 pieces of ammunition. A creature subjected to this poison must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Poison DC.

On failure, they become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a creatures takes {@damage 1d4} necrotic damage at the start of their turn, and are under the effect of {@spell bane}. At the end of a {@condition poisoned} creature's turn, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the condition on success.
Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying, and wears off of a weapon after that weapon has delivered the effect 5 times.

item.name: Wondrous Feast
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this hearty meal, you become satiated for the next 24 hours. You gain the benefits for a {@item common feast|KTKCG}, but can gain additional benefits by trading in Hit Dice that would be gained as part of your next long rest after consuming this meal. These Hit Dice are consumed after calculating how many you would have after the rest (including the benefits of the feast), but you can trade Hit Dice in this way you would normally lose if you have more than your maximum Hit Dice.
You can trade Hit Dice in this way up to a number equal to your proficiency bonus. The benefits scale based on the rarity on the feast.

entries.name: Rare Benefits
items: Roll a {@dice d6} per Hit Die traded and gain temporary hit points equal to the value rolled.
Trade three Hit Dice for an additional spell slot of 2nd level.
Gain a point that can be expended like Inspiration by trading 4 Hit Dice per point.

entries: Any benefit from a feast fades after 24 hours.

item.name: Workshop Key
entries: While attuned to this key, you can can use it to cast {@spell dimensional workshop|KTKCG} without expending a spell slot. Once you use it, you cannot use it again until dawn the next day.

item.name: Wrath
entries: A jagged chaotic rune that spreads out in all directions and flashes with angry red light.

entries.name: Passive Effect
entries: When marked on an item, the attuned wearer can use their reaction to inflict {@damage 1d6} lightning damage on any creature within 30 feet of them that deals damage to them.

entries.name: Active Effect
entries: While attuned to an item with this rune, you can use that item to cast {@spell chain lightning} without expending a spell slot. Once activated, it can't be activated again until the next dawn.

item.name: Yves' Thieves' Tools
entries: You have a +1 bonus to ability checks using these {@item thieves' tools|PHB}. As an action you can hold these tools up to a door to hear through it, as long as it's no thicker than 1 foot, alerting you to the location of any creatures within 20 feet of the door. If you set off a trap while using these tools to pick a lock, you have advantage on any saving throws to resist the trap.
{@note Item and art by {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers}}

itemGroup.name: Alchemical Acid
entries: A small flask of burbling acid, a strange hissing green viscous liquid. It deals {@damage 4d4} acid damage when poured on an object. Can be used as a simple ranged weapon with the thrown (20/60) property, dealing {@damage 4d4} acid damage on hit. You do not add your modifier to the damage roll.

itemGroup.name: Alchemical Fire
entries: A small flask of volatile orange liquid. It deals {@damage 2d10} fire damage when poured on an object. Can be used as a simple ranged weapon with the thrown (20/60) property, dealing {@damage 2d10} fire damage on hit. You do not add your modifier to the damage roll.

itemGroup.name: Amplifying Crystal
itemGroup.reqAttune: by a psionic character with one or more psi points
entries: While holding this crystal, you gain a bonus to psionics attack rolls and to the psionic saving throw DCs of your psionic abilities. The bonus is determined by the crystal's rarity. In addition, when you use a psionic power, you can gain add a number of psi points determined by the crystal's rarity; these points can only be used on psionic powers, but can exceed your normal psi limit. You can't use this property again until you finish a long rest.

itemGroup.name: Essence
entries: Used for {@book Alchemy|KTKCG|10}, {@book Enchanting|KTKCG|14}, {@book Scroll Scribing|KTKCG|15}, {@book Wand Whittling|KTKCG|16}.

itemGroup.name: Fresh Ingredient
entries: A fresh ingredient is something you harvest that can increase the quality of your food and sometimes provide supernatural boosts beyond mere satiation.
Used for {@book Cooking|KTKCG|13}.

itemGroup.name: Ingot
entries: Smelting ore requires specialized factilities. This can usually be accomplished in a fully equiped smithy, but consult your GM for where it might be appropriate. Adventurers rarely smelt their own ore, these are included primarily for informational purposes. Smelting magical ores may require more specialized facilities or locations.

itemGroup.name: Leather
entries: Used for {@book Leatherworking|KTKCG|17}.

itemGroup.name: Lesser Wand
entries: This wand has 3 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast the spell infused in it it. For 1 charge, you cast the base version of the spell. You can increase the spell slot level by one for each additional charge you expend (if applicable for the spell). The DC of the spell is crafter's Wand DC.
The wand doesn't regain charges naturally, but can be recharged (see recharge rules for Lesser Wands).
Lesser wands that cast 3rd-level spells or higher require attunement to use.

itemGroup.name: Magical Ink
entries: Magical ink that is used by Enchanters to create scrolls, made by rendering down magical alchemical ingredients.
Used for {@book Scroll Scribing|KTKCG|15}.

itemGroup.name: Meat
entries: Used for {@book Cooking|KTKCG|13}.

itemGroup.name: Meat Feast
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this hearty meal, you become satiated for the next 24 hours. Consuming the essence of a properly prepared creature of great power confers some of its power to you while satiated by the feast.

You can add [+1/+2/+3/+4] to ability checks and saving throws of the prepared creatures highest stat (if multiple stats are tied, the cook chooses which when preparing the meal). Alternatively, the cook can bring forth exotic properties of the creature, conferring one trait of the cooked animal to those that consume it as per the following table (this replaces the benefit to ability checks and saves):

The details from the creature boon can be found on the creature stat block. The cook must be aware of the creature's property to make the meal imbue that property, and the GM may adjust the property in cases where it would not work for players or be too powerful as written. At the GM's discretion, any ability can be added to this list.

itemGroup.name: Ore
entries: Smelting ore requires specialized factilities. This can usually be accomplished in a fully equiped smithy, but consult your GM for where it might be appropriate. Adventurers rarely smelt their own ore, these are included primarily for informational purposes. Smelting magical ores may require more specialized facilities or locations.

itemGroup.name: Psi Blade Crystal
entries: Embedded in a ring, braclet, bladeless sword hilt, or similar item, this small gem seems to have minimal value to the casual observer, but has perfect psionic resonance.

While carried by a {@class Mystic|UATheMysticClass|Way of the Soul Knife Monk|Soul Knife|UATheMysticClass}, that monk can use this crystal to focus a purer {@subclassFeature Soul Knife|Mystic|UATheMysticClass|Soul Knife|UATheMysticClass|1|UATheMysticClass|Soul Knife}, adding +1/+2/+3 (based on rarity) to attack and damage rolls with their {@subclassFeature Soul Knife|Mystic|UATheMysticClass|Soul Knife|UATheMysticClass|1|UATheMysticClass|Soul Knife}.
Some crystals come in various colors, and change the hue of your psi blade to match the color of the crystal.

itemGroup.name: Reagent
entries: Used for {@book Alchemy|KTKCG|10}, {@book Poisoncraft|KTKCG|11}.

itemGroup.name: Scroll
entries: A spell scroll bears the words of a single spell, written as a mystical cipher. If the spell is on your class's spell list, you can read the scroll and cast its spell without providing any material components. Otherwise, the scroll is unintelligible. Casting the spell by reading the scroll requires the spell's normal casting time. Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and it crumbles to dust. If the casting is interrupted, the scroll is not lost.

If the spell is on your class's spell list but of a higher level than you can normally cast, you must make an ability check using your spellcasting ability to determine whether you cast it successfully. The DC is 10 + the spell's level. On a failed check, the spell disappears from the scroll with no other effect.
Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and the scroll itself crumbles to dust.

itemGroup.name: Simple Explosive
entries: A bundled explosive alchemical preparation. It can be detonated by dealing 1 fire or lightning damage to it. As an action, a packet of this explosive can be accurately thrown 20 feet, but will not detonate on impact (usually). When it detonates, all creatures within 10 feet (for common) of the target point must make a Dexterity saving throw with a DC equal to the crafter's Alchemy DC. On failure, they take {@damage 1d8} fire + {@damage 1d8} thunder damage, or half as much on a success. Creatures in range of more than one explosive take damage only from the highest damage effect.

itemGroup.name: Uncommon Feast
entries: Up to 5 creatures can consume this feast within an hour of it being prepared. After consuming this hearty meal, you become satiated for the next 24 hours. You gain the benefits for a {@item common feast|KTKCG}, but can gain additional benefits by trading in Hit Dice that would be gained as part of your next long rest after consuming this meal. These Hit Dice are consumed after calculating how many you would have after the rest (including the benefits of the feast), but you can trade Hit Dice in this way you would normally lose if you have more than your maximum Hit Dice.
You can trade Hit Dice in this way up to a number equal to your proficiency bonus. The benefits scale based on the rarity on the feast.
Any benefit from a feast fades after 24 hours.
{@note Unsure if this should exist or if it's a typo/generic shorthand for all reagent types?}

An attachment to crossbows. When equipped, the crossbow no longer has the {@itemProperty LD||loading} property, though gains a "reload 5" feature, and must be reloaded as an action or a bonus action after firing 5 times.

This is a magical piece of ammunition carved with pirate motifs. This piece of ammunition changes size to fit the size of the weapon used (becoming large when loaded into a large weapon). You can use this piece of ammunition to cast {@footnote translocating shot|{@note This spell was not found in this source or in any source yet converted.}}{@sup K} once without expending a spell, targeting this piece of ammunition. Once used in this way, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

This special piece of ammunition entangles a target it hits. On hit, a Large or smaller target must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, or become {@condition restrained}, as if by a {@item net|PHB}.

inherits.reqAttune: by a creature that is proficient with shortbows or longbows
entries: You gain a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, it has 5 charges. While holding it, you can expend 1 charge as an action and draw the bowstring, causing two gleaming arrows of magical force to materialize. You immediately fire each arrow at a creature that you can see within 600 feet of you. You can direct the arrows at one creature or multiple, and each arrow automatically hits its target, striking simultaneously.

You can choose to expend additional charges as part of the same action to fire one extra arrow per charge expended. Each arrow deals force damage equal to {@damage 1d6} + your proficiency bonus. The bow regains {@dice 1d4 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the bow's last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the bow retains its {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls but loses all other properties.
{@note Item by "TAG" (TheArenaGuy) of {@link Spectre Creations|https://www.spectrecreations.com/}}

This is a special shot that contains a dangerous rocket like propellant accelerating it to greater speed and distance. This shot can be fired at a weapon's long range without disadvantage, and does an additional weapon die of damage on hit. However, targets gain twice the bonus to AC from cover against this shot as they are difficult to arc.

This weapon is perfectly attuned to conducting psionic energy. While wielding it, you gain the {@psionic Psionic Weapon|UATheMysticClass} talent, but it can only be used when targeting this weapon. When you use {@psionic Psionic Weapon|UATheMysticClass}, the weapons gains a bonus to attack and damage rolls equal to the number of psi points spent, up to a maximum of +3 with three psi points spent.

entries.name: Academic Tradition
entries: The runes of mages, scholars, and elves, these traditions are not necessarily any less ancient, but runecarvers of these traditions seek new knowledge and expression, rather than being rooted in the old ways. Your ability modifier for this tradition is Intelligence, and you can select your related tool from {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|PHB} or {@item Woodcarver's Tools|PHB}.

entries.name: Ancient Tradition
entries: The runes of the Giants, Dwarves, and other ancient traditions. Your ability modifier for this tradition is Wisdom, and you can select your related tool from {@item Mason's Tools|PHB} or {@item Painter's Supplies|PHB}.

itemProperty.name: Exotic
entries: {@note See {@book Appendix E: Exotic Materials|KTKCG|26}.}

itemProperty.name: Example Template
entries: {@note This is an example {@book Blacksmithing|KTKCG|12} template weapon.}

entries.name: Loud
entries: Your weapon rings with thunder that is audible within 300 feet of you whenever it makes an attack.

itemProperty.name: Psionic
entries: {@note This item's power is psionic in nature.}

entries.name: Reload 5
entries: This weapon must be reloaded as an action or a bonus action after firing 5 times.

entries.name: Stormcharged
entries: When you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a Stormcharged Weapon, you can make only one Attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make. If you could otherwise make additional attacks with that action, the weapon deals an extra 3d6 lightning or thunder damage per attack that was foregone.

itemType.name: Component
entries: A component used in {@book crafting|KTKCG|1}.

variantrule.name: Actual Blacksmithing
entries: {@i Actual blacksmiths have opinions}

Since posting this system, I've heard from plenty of actual blacksmiths, letting me know blacksmithing is hard. This system is a model that balances game mechanics, fun, practicality, and realism in equal parts, but if you want a system that will make them happier, double all blacksmithing times, and triple armor crafting time per check. This means that making 1 check would for weapons or items would be 4 hours, and making 1 check for armor would take 6 hours.

I would recommend only using this variant when downtime is plentiful, or when combined with the "{@variantrule Assistance|KTKCG}" variant rules. When combined with the {@variantrule assistance|KTKCG} variant rules, the maximum number of helpers remains 3 (each reducing the time to make a check by 1 hour still).

variantrule.name: Assistance
entries: {@i Group-based crafting and minions}
When being assisted by a skilled craftsman (who has proficiency in the related tool and skills of the crafting branch), you gain advantage on the crafting roll.

If one roll succeeds, the check passes and the crafting continues as normal. If both of your rolls succeed, it counts as twice as much progress. If both of the rolls would be a failure, it counts as two failures and no progress is made. Too many cooks in a kitchen can be dangerous! More than one helper when crafting this method doesn't have additional benefits.

If you are using the "{@variantrule Taking 10|KTKCG|take 10}" approach during downtime crafting, you can pick the most skilled crafter's modifier to the crafting roll to use. Each additional person assisting during downtime crafting, the period crafting time per check is reduced by 1 hour to a minimum of 1 hour (with three helpers). People can only qualify as helpers if they have proficiency in the tool being used for the crafting project.

variantrule.name: Crafting Skill
entries: {@i Artisanal skills that aren't tied to how good at slaying monsters you happen to be}

This is an alternative to using proficiency. This was the original plan, but ultimately proved unnecessarily complicated for general use, but some people prefer the sense of progression and realism from having a crafting skill that isn't tied to your combat prowess.

entries.name: Progression and Progress
entries: Each branch of crafting will have a different way to gain skill in that field, typically involving a variety of options for gaining each level of a skill. These are not intended to be something gained easily or quickly, and scale on a quite exponential scale. Achieving skill 3 or 4 is fairly easy for adventurers, while skill 5 and 6 would be what is achieved at the end game, and level 7 is possible, but out of reach for most adventurers. Here is a simple method of progression:
If you combine with the {@variantrule innovation system|KTKCG}, you can award double credit for any gold pieces of materials spent attempting to innovate a new item when tracking skill progression.

variantrule.name: Gritty Realism
entries: {@i For games that move at a more deliberate pace}

The normal crafting time listed in this book is balanced around a progression of minimal downtime with 8 hour long rests. For games that follow the model of 8 hour short rests and week long long rests offering more downtime, you can still use this system, but may want to consider longer crafting checks.
To accomplish this, make each crafting check take 8 hours (four times longer). This maps to one work day per crafting check. In addition:

items: Checks do not have to be subsequent for any crafting branch (including {@book Alchemy|KTKCG|10}).
{@variantrule Taking 10|KTKCG} for checks takes two consecutive workdays.
Gathering checks require one week when gathering from environment.

variantrule.name: How Feast Spent Dice Work
entries: If, for example, at level 4, if you start a rest with 2 Hit Dice, and consume a meal that would give an additional Hit Die, you would end the rest with 5, but your maximum is 4, so you would lose the 5th. This allows you to spend that extra fifth Hit Die for additional benefits. You could spend 3 Hit Dice on these benefits, but doing so would mean you only have 2 Hit Dice after the long rest.

variantrule.name: Innovation System
entries: {@i Making it so you have to actually know how to make the things you make}

Adding back in some complexity Almost all enchanting recipes use scrolls as blueprints for the magic of the item and essences to power it. It is possible that other methods exist, the scroll is fundamentally a blueprint of the magic the item uses, as well part of its magical essence that is imbued into it. A GM can opt to replace the scroll with a blueprint or innovation check (see variant rules) and additional magical essences (to replace both the knowledge and power provided by the scroll).

entries.name: Variant: Recipes
entries: Materials are just stuff without a recipe. Coming in the form of techniques, blueprints, or any one of a hundred different forms of knowledge, the an essential step of making anything is know how.

A recipe alone doesn't inherently grant success—a recipe is just a path that the craftsman can walk, but final product will come down to their skills, materials, and a little luck. Even so, recipes are not created equal. The technique of swordcraft left behind by a grand master of the craft can contain knowledge that will inherently boost the skills of anyone following its techniques.
Like materials, recipes can come from three sources:

items.name: Found:
entries: The world you adventure in is often vast and dotted with the legacies of those that have come before. Frequently ancient techniques and secrets can be uncovered during your adventurers, hoarded by dragons (...or maybe kobolds earlier in your adventures!).

items.name: Purchased:
entries: As with most things, money can bridge many gaps and provide many answers. Either convincing a craftsman to teach you their technique or buying a potion formula from the alchemists guild, most people in the world will understand that they stand to more to gain by selling fish than by teaching their customers how to fish, so these will won't come cheap, but can often by attained by establishing good relations... or just dropping a lot of coin.

entries.name: How much do Recipes cost?
entries: How much a recipe costs, or even if it's available, has a lot of factors behind it and is ultimately up to the GM, but in general be fairly expensive (to encourage innovation) but not outrageous compared to what they make. Roughly 10 times the cost of the materials to make the item.

items.name: Invented!:
entries: While many craftsmen and craftswoman tread in the footsteps of others, those at the cutting edge are those that innovate and invent, stepping beyond what is known (to them). More difficult, a recipe is created through trial and effort, and will frequently leave many broken prototypes as proof of the effort.

To invent a recipe, you make an innovation check. This takes 1 hour, and once attempted cannot be attempted again until you finish a long rest. You can select materials to expend on the innovation check.

items: If you roll half the innovation difficult or more and did not have the correct materials, you learn the materials needed for the recipe (this doesn't require any materials to be expended).
If you roll half the innovation difficult or more of the recipe and had the correct ingredients, you learn the innovation difficulty of the recipe and materials needed for the recipe.

If you roll the innovation difficult with all the required ingredients spent toward the check, you learn the recipe, and this counts as the first successful crafting roll toward crafting the product of that recipe.

On failure, all materials put toward the check are lost. On success, the recipe is learned, and the materials can be rolled over toward crafting the item; the first crafting check for the item automatically succeeds on that crafting attempt.

entries: The GM can set the innovation DC of an item, or just have it default to the DC of an innovation check is the Crafting DC of the item +5.
An innovation roll is as follows:

entries.name: Recipe Innovation Roll
entries.text: d20 + your relevant crafting Skill + your Wisdom or Intelligence modifier (your choice)

entries: However a player has acquired their recipes, they are encouraged to record their recipes in a book or manual.

entries.name: Losing Your Recipes:
entries: Recipes are usually going to be recorded as physical documents, and consequently must be safeguarded. If a set of Recipes are lost, it will be up to the GM to determine how many they might remember by heart.

The following is my recommendation: half their recipes + the intelligence modifier are known by heart. Recipes remembered are chosen in the order of Invented Recipes > Most Crafted Recipe > Most Recently Crafted Recipe, and then ordered by which have been used the most to the least.
{@feat Keen Mind|PHB|Certain feats} or abilities may negate any recipes lost.

variantrule.name: More Common Magic
entries: {@i Not just for enchanters}

While magical items is generally thought of as the domain of {@book enchanters|KTKCG|14}, a skilled crafter with the correct knowledge may be able to craft certain magic items with this variant rule. If you have proficiency in {@skill Arcana}, you can use your crafting skill to craft items from certain enchanting tables as per the table below. When making items this way, you can only make items of types you can normally make.
If another creature proficient in {@skill arcana} assists for the full duration of the craft, they can serve as a replacement for proficiency in arcana.

variantrule.name: Old School
entries: {@i Experience-based crafting}

In the olden days crafting checks took experience as a fundamentally component. This is not a feature of this system, but the following is a variant for those that want to run a hateful and archaic system that will cause great suffering. In this system, certain components can be (or must, as per your GM), be replaced with experience, using the following ratios:

entries.name: Arcanist Crafting
entries: This harkens back to the tales of the Arcanists of certain ancient empires investing their very life force and power in magic items, and somewhat models the system as presented in early editions. I don't necessarily recommend it for 5e, and this isn't how I run crafting, but I wouldn't to present the option here. This will make magic items more of an investment, but easier to access.

variantrule.name: Recharging Lesser Wands
entries: Recharging lesser wands is fairly simple; you can either expend 1 essence of the rarity required to craft that wand and perform a ritual that takes 2 hours, expending the essence and restoring all charges to the Lesser Wand (this only works with Lesser Wands), or you can expend 2 spell slots equal to the level of the spell the wand can cast (1st level for cantrip) during this ritual to recharge a single charge; you can repeat this ritual to recharge the wand multiple times, up to its maximum charges.

variantrule.name: Taking 10
entries: When you craft something, double the crafting period (from 2 hours to 4 hours per check) to "take a 10"on the crafting roll, meaning that your crafting checks are 10 + your related ability score + your related tool proficiency bonus. This provides a floor level that you can always succeed on if you choose to take your time.
If someone with proficiency is aiding you for the entire duration of the crafting, the crafting check doesn't gain any bonus, but can be completed in the standard 2 hours.

entries.name: NPC Crafting
entries: It should always be assumed that when NPCs are crafting, they take this option, and thus craft more slowly but reliably. The slap-dash speed crafting is largely the domain of the players, though at the GM's discretion the players may convince a NPC to craft faster assuming the risk of their materials.

table.name: Additional Materials
intro: You can simply load more reagents into any potion, increasing its potency in different ways, though it increases the difficulty. You can make a "custom potion" simply by using these modifiers with no base potion. When you do so, the base DC is 8.

The potion deals +{@damage 1d4} fire damage when shattered (or consumed).

table.name: Alchemy Modifiers
intro: The following are alchemical modifiers that can be applied to a potion. All alchemical modifiers require approval from the GM if the modifier will work with a given potion or creation.
rows: Require two additional {@item reactive reagent|KTKCG|reactive reagents} of equal rarity to the rarest reagent of the potion. Rather than drinking it, when uncorked or broken (as an action) it effects all creatures in a 5-foot radius as if they'd consumed it.
Requires an {@item common divine essence|KTKCG}. Adds the effect of {@spell lesser restoration} to the potion.
Requires an {@item rare divine essence|KTKCG}. Adds the effect of {@spell greater restoration} to the potion.
Any fire damage the potion does becomes cold damage.
Requires an additional {@item common reactive reagent|KTKCG}. Expands the area of effect of any area of effect the potion has by 5 feet.

The effect of the potion becomes shrouded from magic such as {@spell identify}. You can make the potion appear as another potion of the same rarity. Another alchemist can identify it by making an Alchemy Check against your Alchemy DC.

footnotes: {@sup MW} Masterwork: Failing a crafting roll for Masterwork doesn't cause a failure, but the resulting weapon is only a Masterwork if all crafting rolls succeed pass the DC of Masterwork. An item is automatically masterwork if every roll qualified for a Masterwork version.

table.name: Material Modifiers
rows: Weapons forged from Bronze are inferior, having −1 to attack and damage rolls. Gains the Fragile property.
Armor forged from bronze is inferior, having a −1 penalty to its AC. Gains the Fragile property.

Gains the "Special: Critical Strikes with this weapon permanently damage nonmagical weapons, shields or armor of the defending creature that are not forged from Adamantine (reducing the attack roll of a weapon or the AC of armor by 2)".
While you're wearing it, any critical hit against you becomes a normal hit.

A weapon with the {@itemProperty H||heavy} property forged from it loses the {@itemProperty H||heavy} property. If the weapon didn't have the {@itemProperty H||heavy} property, it gains the {@itemProperty L||light} property. The DC of an Enchanter applying an Enchantment to it is reduced by 4, and it always counts has having 1 {@item common essence|KTKCG} of any type as part of the craft.
If the armor normally imposes disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks or has a Strength requirement, the mithral version of the armor doesn't. Easier for Enchanters to Enchant.
You have advantage on attack rolls while in darkness wielding Darksteel weapons.
{@skill Perception} checks relying on sight have disadvantage against you when you are in dim light or darkness while wearing this armor.
A weapon forged from icesteel deals an extra {@damage 1d4} cold damage on hit.
Wearing armor forged from icesteel grants resistance to Fire damage.
A weapon forged from firesteel deals an extra {@damage 1d4} fire damage on hit.
Wearing armor forged from firesteel grants resistance to Cold damage.
